title: Quiz 2: FQE June 2017 Paper 1
description: Reproductive Health Final Qualifying Exam - June 2017 (Paper 1) covering obstructed labor, infertility, abortion, and clinical scenarios converted to interactive formats.

questions.question: Which of the following are recognized causes of obstructed labor? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Obstructed labor is caused by mechanical blockage: CPD, malpresentation/position, fetal anomalies (hydrocephalus), or pelvic tumors/deformities. PROM itself causes leakage but not obstruction.
questions.hint: Think about mechanical barriers preventing the baby from passing through the pelvis.

questions.question: Identify the clinical signs suggestive of obstructed labor. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Signs include Bandl's ring (impending rupture), severe moulding/caput, edematous vulva, maternal distress (tachycardia, dehydration), and fetal distress.
questions.hint: Look for signs of prolonged pressure and maternal exhaustion.

questions.question: Match the cause of infertility with the correct partner (Male/Female):
questions.explanation: Varicocele, Retrograde Ejaculation, Azoospermia are Male causes. Tubal Blockage, PCOS, Endometriosis are Female causes.

questions.question: Which of the following are key components of Post Abortal Care (PAC)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: PAC involves treating the complication (evacuation), counseling, providing contraception to prevent recurrence, linking to other health services, and community partnership. Inducing pregnancy immediately is not a component.
questions.hint: Think about the holistic care needed after a pregnancy loss to prevent future unsafe abortions.

questions.question: Identify the predisposing factors for Fetal Distress. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Factors include cord accidents, placental issues (abruption/previa), maternal issues (hypotension, anemia, pre-eclampsia), and uterine hyperstimulation. Normal movement is a sign of wellbeing.
questions.hint: Anything that reduces oxygen supply to the fetus is a risk factor.

questions.question: Match the '4 Ts' of Postpartum Hemorrhage causes with their descriptions:
questions.explanation: Tone (Atony), Trauma (Injury), Tissue (Retained products), Thrombin (Clotting defects).
questions.hint: The mnemonic helps classify the etiology of bleeding.

questions.question: Rehema, 36 years old, presents with post-coital bleeding and cervical erosion. Which of the following are appropriate SCREENING methods for Cervical Cancer? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Screening methods include Pap smear, VIA, VILI, and HPV testing. Radical Hysterectomy is a treatment, not a screening method.
questions.hint: Which of these are tests used to detect the disease early?

questions.question: Maria presents with Preterm Premature Rupture of Membranes (PPROM) at 32 weeks. Order the management steps:

items.text: Admit and confirm diagnosis (Sterile speculum exam)
Plan delivery at 34 weeks or if infection/distress develops

questions.explanation: 1. Admit/Diagnose (avoid digital exam). 2. Steroids are crucial at 32w. 3. Antibiotics prolong latency. 4. Delivery is the endpoint (usually at 34w or if complications arise).

questions.question: Nafula (17yo, 34 weeks) presents with severe headache, epigastric pain, and BP 180/115 mmHg. Which of the following management principles apply to Severe Pre-eclampsia/Imminent Eclampsia? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Administer Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4) for seizure prophylaxis
Delay delivery for 4 weeks to allow fetal growth
Monitor fluid balance strictly to prevent pulmonary edema

questions.explanation: In severe pre-eclampsia/imminent eclampsia, the priorities are: Prevent seizures (MgSO4), Control BP, and Deliver. Delaying for weeks is dangerous for the mother. Delivery is the only cure.
questions.hint: This is a hypertensive emergency. Prolonging pregnancy puts the mother's life at risk.

questions.question: What is the diagnosis for a patient with BP 180/115 mmHg, proteinuria, severe headache, and epigastric pain?
questions.explanation: The presence of severe hypertension (BP >160/110) combined with 'severe features' (headache, epigastric pain) defines Severe Pre-eclampsia or Imminent Eclampsia.
questions.hint: It's a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy, specifically the severe form before seizures occur.
